s.text: For instance, we are told that "foreign policy was secondary [to German unity] in Hitler's intentions," although Hitler saw these aims as inseparable--invoking, in Mein Kampf , Germany's need for "living space" ( lebensraum ) and her "moral right to acquire foreign land and soil."
Nor did Hitler try to abolish capitalism, as Lukacs suggests, although, like his adversary Roosevelt, he did expand state supervision of private industry.
As a result, he succeeded, in less than a decade, in making himself the ruler of Europe from the gates of Moscow to the English Channel.

Despite his penchant for revolutionary rhetoric, his inspired use of modern techniques of collective mobilization, and his willingness to strike up a tactical alliance with Stalin, Hitler remained a committed foe of what he called "Jew-Bolshevism," and indeed, of all leveling ideologies.

Despite his penchant for revolutionary rhetoric, his inspired use of modern techniques of collective mobilization, and his willingness to strike up a tactical alliance with Stalin, Hitler remained a committed foe of what he called "Jew-Bolshevism," and indeed, of all leveling ideologies.
"During the twentieth century the compound of nationalism with socialism has become the nearly universal practice for all states ...
Nor did Hitler try to abolish capitalism, as Lukacs suggests, although, like his adversary Roosevelt, he did expand state supervision of private industry.

Often dismissed as a poor military strategist intoxicated by quixotic ambitions, Hitler was in fact extremely adept at sizing up his opponents' weaknesses and understood acutely the "supreme importance of land power" with the "motorization of military movement."

For instance, we are told that "foreign policy was secondary [to German unity] in Hitler's intentions," although Hitler saw these aims as inseparable--invoking, in Mein Kampf , Germany's need for "living space" ( lebensraum ) and her "moral right to acquire foreign land and soil."

Often dismissed as a poor military strategist intoxicated by quixotic ambitions, Hitler was in fact extremely adept at sizing up his opponents' weaknesses and understood acutely the "supreme importance of land power" with the "motorization of military movement."
Hillgruber added his own provocative twist by proclaiming that German historians were obliged to "identify" with the German soldiers on the Eastern front who were protecting Germany from Bolshevism.
